Award.AwardTitle: Science-Driven Cyberinfrastructure: Integrating Permafrost Data, Services, and Research Applications
Award.AbstractNarration:
Science-Driven Cyberinfrastructure: Integrating permafrost data, services, and research applications

This project proposes the use of cyberinfrastructure tools for providing services to the scientific community for accessing and discovering selected permafrost datasets. Permafrost is deemed as an Environmental Indicator and an Essential Climate Variable by agencies monitoring the Earth?s climate. Improved access to permafrost datasets (currently scattered over many places on the web) is necessary for better understanding its current and past state. Global scientific and policy communities need comprehensive, up-to-date maps of permafrost distribution and status. By making permafrost data easier to use, this project supports data integration work currently duplicated by every lab using permafrost data and will advance knowledge by freeing critical time for unique research. Project outcomes are directly useful to policy-makers, broader science researchers, indigenous communities, community-based monitoring programs, and others living on or in close proximity to and studying permafrost.

Through science-driven cyberinfrastructure, the research team will produce a set of scalable, multi-faceted services to address the complexity of permafrost data access and usability. Recognizing the importance of coordinated efforts in this area, the project will start where previous efforts left off. This research leverages progress in International Permafrost Association and Global Terrestrial Network - Permafrost (GTN-P) cyberinfrastructure, advances permafrost community interests, and contributes valuable functionality and data to this necessary system. Specific project objectives are: 1) Aggregate, extract, pre-process, standardize, and reorganize data from beyond the GTN-P network in a cost-effective manner, increasing the breadth and depth of the GTN-P system by integrating valuable data holdings from the National Snow and Ice Data Center (NSIDC) Frozen Ground Data Center (FGDC) and Advanced Cooperative Arctic Data and Information Service (ACADIS) Gateway. 2) Extend semantic infrastructure by expanding the GTN-P ontology to include broader permafrost and climate modeling concepts and terms for data discovery, integration, and reuse. 3) Integrate GTN-P metadata and systems into the Arctic Data Explorer distributed search portal, and Arctic Observing Viewer data collection map to support federated data access. 4) Improve data usability by developing visualization services that quickly produce customized maps at multiple spatial scales to deliver information to researchers, citizen scientists, and policy makers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The PermaData project took old, forgotten measurements of permafrost temperature and integrated them into the Global Terrestrial Network for Permafrost (GTN-P) data system for use by the broader scientific community.  Permafrost is permanently frozen ground that occurs in 24% of the northern hemisphere land area.  For various reasons over the last 100 years, countries and corporations drilled boreholes hundreds of meters into the permafrost and hung down thermometers to measure temperature, a key measure of permafrost health.  In recent years, many of these measurements have appeared on the internet, but not in a form that anyone can readily use.  Each data file had a different structure and used a different format, such as text, spreadsheets, or even scanned images of paper documents.  Such measurements have great scientific value, but remained inaccessible because of the massive time and effort required to organize and combine hundreds of files into a single, useful dataset.  We created the tools and infrastructure to clean up and organize all this data and move them into the GNT-P so people can use them.

To clean up and organize the data files, we developed the Data Integration Tool (DIT).  Each data file had a unique structure and format based on who collected the data and why, requiring in a unique work flow to prepare it for GTN-P.  Although each file had a unique work flow, the individual steps are remarkably similar.  We subdivided data processing into small steps and created packages of code called widgets for each.  We developed 75 DIT widgets that calculate statistics, identify bad data values, perform math, replace text, reformat dates, etc.  DIT allows the user to select the operations and the order as required to process each data file (https://github.com/PermaData/DIT).  DIT has proven extremely useful and we now use it to organize a variety of data from different scientific disciplines.

We added temperature measurements from 650 boreholes into the GTN-P, increasing the number of sites to 1510 (Figure 1).  Previously, the GTN-P focused on active boreholes drilled in the 1980s where people still collect temperature measurements.  However, most of the measurements we added to GTN-P came from boreholes that people abandoned between 1960 and 1990.  Some of the measurements date back to the 1940s and the earliest record starts in 1890.  The temperature measurements we added to the GTN-P extends our observational record back in time so that we can better understand the impacts of climate change on permafrost.

One of the reasons the data files differed so much is that everyone uses different terms to describe the same thing, so we developed a preliminary permafrost ontology.  An ontology is an organized set of ideas and terms showing their properties and the relations between them.  We started with the US Permafrost Association glossary (https://www.uspermafrost.org/glossary.php) and identified relationships between terms, such as closely related terms, synonyms, and antonyms.  Any effective ontology requires community engagement and agreement, so we organized working groups as part of several international initiatives to monitor climate change in the Arctic.  These working groups will continue development of the permafrost ontology after the end of this project. 

To engage permafrost experts, we developed a tool to visualize the relationships between terms using an online browser (Figure 2).  A user selects terms in the ontology with a query and the tool graphically displays the relationships between the selected terms.  We chose this approach to allow access to the tool and ontology by the entire global permafrost community via the internet.  We constructed the ontology using globally adopted standards so that other software tools can readily use our permafrost ontology.  The prototype ontology tool provides a foundation for the scientific community to develop a full permafrost ontology.
